DT Article
TI NEW SPECIES OF NEOPANORPA (MECOPTERA) FROM VIETNAM, WITH A KEY TO THE
   SPECIES OF MECOPTERA OF VIETNAM.
AU Bicha, Wesley J. (mecoptera@live.com) 
   Schiff, Nathan
   Thai Hong Pham
   Lancaster, Aaron
   Scheffler, Brian
SO Proceedings of the Entomological Society of Washington
VL 119
IS 4
PS 529-544
PD Oct 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Sixteen species of scorpionflies have been reported from Vietnam,
   consisting of 13 Neopanorpa and three Bittacus species. One of these
   scorpionflies from the Central Highlands of Vietnam with hood-shaped
   hypovalves was determined to be a new species and is described herein as
   Neopanorpa cucullata, n.sp. A second new species, Neopanorpa
   ellengreeni, n.sp., with golden yellow wing membranes and Y-shaped wing
   markings is described from northern Vietnam. COI DNA analysis of 16 of
   17 species of Vietnamese Mecoptera are presented using a
   neighbor-joining tree indicating that the new species are approximately
   as distinct from the extant species as the extant species are from each
   other. A key is provided for all 17 Vietnamese Mecoptera.
C1 Bicha, Wesley J.; Trop Res Associates Entomol, 521 46th St, Sacramento,
   CA, 95819, USA, USA.
EM mecoptera@live.com

   Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   [Phylogeny /  / ] [Vietnam /  / Key to genera & species] [ /  / ]. 
   Neopanorpa cucullata; Neopanorpa ellengreeni [Vietnam /  / New species].

DT Article
TI A SECOND SPECIES OF HETEROPLEA COOK (HEMIPTERA: PLEIDAE).
AU Cook, Jerry L. (jcook@shsu.edu) 
SO Proceedings of the Entomological Society of Washington
VL 119
IS 4
PS 545-550
PD Oct 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 3
U2 4
AB Heteroplea is a Neotropical genus of Pleidae that is easily separated
   from other members of the family by having a distinct raised callus on
   the dorsal posterior of the head and sharing a 3,3,3 tarsal formula with
   the Palearctic genus Plea. Heteroplea acanthoscelis, n. sp. is described
   and can be differentiated from all other species of Pleidae in having
   raptorial spines on its prothoracic tibia, with smaller, similar spines
   on the mesothoracic tibia. With this description, H. acanthoscelis n.
   sp. becomes the second member of this genus; both species are currently
   known only from Venezuela.
C1 Cook, Jerry L.; Sam Houston State Univ, Dept Biol Sci, Huntsville, TX,
   77341, USA, USA.
EM jcook@shsu.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8797

   South America

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Nepomorpha,
   Notonectoidea, Pleidae
OR Heteroplea acanthoscelis (Pleidae): [Sp nov, Venezuela, P. 546].

DT Article
TI THE MEALY PLUM APHID AND ITS CONGENERS: A SYNONYMIC REVISION OF THE
   PRUNUS-INFESTING APHID GENUS HYALOPTERUS (HEMIPTERA: APHIDIDAE).
AU Favret, Colin (ColinFavret@AphidNet.org) 
   Meshram, Naresh M.
   Miller, Gary L.
   Nieto Nafria, Juan Manuel
   Stekolshchikov, Andrey V.
SO Proceedings of the Entomological Society of Washington
VL 119
IS 4
PS 565-574
PD Oct 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 2
U2 5
AB The three species of Hyalopterus Koch cause economic damage to various
   stone fruit trees of the genus Prunus L., H. pruni (Geoffroy), H.
   amygdali (Blanchard), and H. persikonus Miller et al. Although the third
   species was established recently, it has been suggested that one of the
   twelve older synonyms of the first two may be applicable to the third.
   We undertook a synonymic revision of the nominal species of Hyalopterus
   to clarify the taxonomy and nomenclature of the genus. The three valid
   species of Hyalopterus are affirmed to be H. pruni (the mealy plum
   aphid), H. amygdali, and H. arundiniformis Ghulamullah, stat. nov. We
   determined that H. mimulus Borner and H. persikonus are junior synonyms
   of H. arundiniformis, syn. nov., and that Brachysiphum kobachidzei
   Rusanova is not a synonym of H. amygdali but a valid species of Aphis,
   stat. nov., comb. nov. Aphis amygdalipersicae Mosley is likely a senior
   synonym of Brachycaudus helichrysi (Kaltenbach), syn. nov.; to maintain
   current usage, we establish the former as a nomen oblitum with respect
   to the latter. Finally, several other nominal species were unevaluable
   and are therefore listed as nomina dubia.
C1 Favret, Colin; Univ Montreal, Dept Biol Sci, 4101 Rue Sherbrooke Est,
   Montreal, PQ, H1X 2B2, Canada, Canada.
EM ColinFavret@AphidNet.org

OI Favret, Colin/0000-0001-6243-3184; Stekolshchikov,
   Andrey/0000-0003-4168-7649
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8797

   Unavailable name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position

   Aphidoidea
OR Aphis amygdalipersicae - Mosley 1841 (Aphidoidea): [Syn nov,
   Brachycaudus helichrysi (Kaltenbach 1843), p. 567; Nomen dubium, P. 567;
   Nomen oblitum, P. 567]. 
   Aphis arundinis - Fabricius 1775 (Aphidoidea): [Nomen dubium, P. 567]. 
   Aphis gracilis - Walker 1852 (Aphidoidea): [Nomen dubium, P. 568]. 
   Aphis kobachidzei - (Rusanova 1941) (Aphidoidea): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Brachysiphum, p. 569]. 
   Aphis persicariae - Hartig 1841 (Aphidoidea): [Nomen dubium, P. 568]. 
   Aphis phragmitidicola - Oestlund 1886 (Aphidoidea): [Nomen dubium, P.
   568]. 
   Aphis prunicerasi - Stewart 1802 (Aphidoidea): [Nomen nudum, P. 569].

   protectum, P. 567].

   synonymy, With Hyalopterus amygdali (Blanchard 1840), p. 569; Referred

   Hyalopterus - Koch 1854 (Aphidoidea): [Revision, Synonymic revision, p.
   565]. 
   Hyalopterus abietinus - Matsumura 1917 (Aphidoidea): [Nomen dubium, P.

   synonymy, Brachysiphum kobachidzei Rusanova 1941, p. 569; Removal from
   synonymy, Hyalopterus arundiniformis Ghulamullah 1942, p. 569; Removal
   from synonymy, Hyalopterus mimulus Boerner 1950, p. 570]. 
   Hyalopterus arundiniformis - Ghulamullah 1942 (Aphidoidea): [Syn nov,

   Hyalopterus mimulus - Boerner 1950 (Aphidoidea): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Hyalopterus amygdali (Blanchard 1840), p. 570]. 
   Hyalopterus pruni - (Geoffroy 1762) (Aphidoidea): [Status, P. 568].

TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF MACROSIPHUM PASSERINI (HEMIPTERA: APHIDIDAE) FROM DRY

VL 119

LA English

AB Two new species of Macrosiphum are described, both of which live in
   similar dry forest habitats of the inland northwestern U.S.A.:
   Macrosiphum dewsler n. sp. from Linum lewisii (Linaceae), and
   Macrosiphum garyreed n. sp. from Geum triflorum (Rosaceae). Information
   is presented about the habitats, host plant biology, distribution, and
   taxonomy of both species.

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF ORMOCERUS WALKER (HYMENOPTERA: PTEROMALIDAE) FROM NORTH
   AMERICA AND A RANGE EXPANSION FOR ORMOCERUS LATUS WALKER.
AU Morin, Hillary D. (hjm5194@psu.edu) 
   Miko, Istvan
   Gates, Michael
SO Proceedings of the Entomological Society of Washington
VL 119
IS 4
PS 619-628
PD Oct 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Ormocerus dirigoius Morin & Gates, n. sp. is described and compared to
   the North American O. americanus Dzhanokmen and Grissell and European
   species O. latus Walker and O. vernalis Walker. A range expansion into
   the Nearctic is reported for O. latus, previously only known from the
   Palearctic. Specimens were collected in Harpswell, Maine during a study
   of the parasitic Hymenoptera community associated with Operophtera
   brumata Linnaeus (Lepidoptera: Geometridae), an invasive species. The
   species are keyed and illustrated using macrophotography and scanning
   electron microphotography.

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF CARINETA AMYOT & AUDINET-SERVILLE, 1843 (HEMIPTERA:
   CICADOIDEA: CICADIDAE) FROM MARTINIQUE.
AU Sanborn, Allen F. (asanborn@barry.edu) 
SO Proceedings of the Entomological Society of Washington
VL 119
IS 4
PS 629-636
PD Oct 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new Caribbean cicada Carineta acclivis Sanborn, new species is
   described and illustrated. This is the second species of Carineta Amyot
   & Audinet-Serville, 1843 described from Martinique and the Lesser
   Antilles. Carineta martiniquensis Davis, 1934 is illustrated and
   distinguished from the new species. The adults of both cicada species on
   Martinique are active in forest habitats and have extended emergence
   periods during the year but appear to be separated by an altitudinal
   gradient.
C1 Sanborn, Allen F.; Barry Univ, Dept Biol, 11300 NE Second Ave, Miami
   Shores, FL, 33161, USA, USA.
EM asanborn@barry.edu
